ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of Japanese Grammar, culture, and vocabulary. Many new kanji.
I developed basic conversional skills by learning more diverse grammatical structure and vocabularies.
I learned more Japanese grammar, vocabulary, and kanji.
I learned how to speak Japanese, write kanji, and form grammatically complex sentences.
More focus on grammar and culture than 110. Gained a lot more flexibility in speaking.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths are the wealth of speaking practice and cultural knowledge that help the student comprehend the language at a deeper level. The biggest weakness is the textbook. This course uses pilot versions of an unreleased TOBIRA I and II textbook. I think this is only because someone at Yale was involved in making it. TOBIRA I is fine, though it still needs some work. TOBIRA II is unpolished and contains many errors, even in Japanese text which is very frustrating for students. A new version of this textbook or a new textbook is needed.

This course requires a bit of daily work put into it in order to keep up with the material, but class time is honestly very fun, and it's such a small group that we become very familiar and comfortable with each other. There's never the feeling of being embarassed to speak in front of other people or of not knowing something. One thing is that you don't get a lot of individual feedback during the semester on the chapter tests, so you just don't ever find out how you did on the tests. That said, there's not really stress about grades as long as you put in the effort.
I really liked the class because the teacher made it really fun. She also teaches in a way easy to understand. At some points, however, I thought that the course was going a bit too fast.
Very high quality, engaging course material. The culturally focused lessons/elements are especially enjoyable!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Due to the nature and pace of the class, learning while having slow or unreliable internet is very difficult. I had a period of periodic internet outages this semester which really made this class difficult, and I wish there had been a way to accommodate for this. Other than that, this class adapted very well to the virtual environment.

The video assignments can take a while but they're really good practice for speaking. Even though the class is completely virtual, basically all of our classtime is interactive and the instructuor really engages the whole class. The instructor is also very understanding of personal situtations during the pandemic and also technical difficulties.
I like how there was both recorded and live lectures.

The content overall was less engaging than I'm sure it is in-person, however there was nothing in particular which stood out as not working well virtually. A lot of effort was made to adapt to the virtual format and was largely successful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would only recommend this course to students with a strong interest in Japanese. The textbook TOBIRA II makes the second part of this course difficult due to errors in Japanese text, strange organization, and a pdf copy that fails to properly match the physical textbook. Additionally, I did not receive much feedback in this course. Grades came only at the end of the semester, and I never really had an idea of how I was doing in the class. The content is interesting, so students who love Japanese should enjoy the course, but those just interested in taking a language should choose a better organized one with a better book.
Yes! It really builds on the materials of JPN 110 and slowly preps you to be ready to hold longer and more complex conversations.
If they want to further their knowledge of Japanese, then I recommend this course. The course does what it needs to do. In a fun an pretty easy way.
I really enjoyed this class! It is a lot of work, but it's well-organized--with every assignment feeling worthwhile--and with especially enjoyable cultural elements mixed in.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Asynchronous assignments for class on Wednesday, but other days of the week are virtual seminar style.
Live virtual lecture and recorded lecture
Virtual seminar
